item.title: By: Brian Davis
item.dc:creator: Brian Davis
item.description:
Thanks for the feedback Allan! I agree, only you know how redundant you need to be and my hope is that those who haven't thought about redundancy for their presentations will start to think about it. It could be something as simple as copying it to a flash drive or it could be much more complex.
I usually travel with both my W530 and my Surface Pro and can usually do what I need to on one or the other if one fails for some reason.

item.title: By: Allan Hirt
item.dc:creator: Allan Hirt
item.description:
As someone who has been doing this a long time, I agree with the overall premise. The Demo Fairy has not always been kind to me (see http://www.sqlha.com/2013/10/18/even-if-you-are-prepared-happens/) which in some way validates your overall purpose behind this post. I am a big fan of redundancy but as I talk about - how redundant do you really need to be? Only you know.
In many places I go or present, I do not have an Internet connection. Azure in theory is a nice idea as a backup, but in reality, not always usable or applicable. Instead of carrying a laptop, I find the small form factor PC (like the NUC or Gigabyte Brix) is a much better alternative. Or, you have a demo PC and the SFF PC (which is how I worked for a bit - proverbial separation of church and state). Some virtualization platforms (read: VMware Workstation) mean the VMs are totally portable, so if they are on an external drive, as long as you can reinstall the hypervisor, you're good. Hyper-V is not like that. So platform choice can play in here, too. I'm not saying the use of Azure is wrong; it's not for some demos. It wouldn't work for a lot of my complex HA demos for various reasons.
